'''24w12a''' is the thirteenth [[snapshot]] for [[Java Edition 1.20.5]], released on March 20, 2024,<ref>{{snap|24w12a|March 20, 2024}}</ref> which fixes bugs, changes the [[heavy core]], adds 7 new [[advancement]]s and adds the [[trial chambers map]].

== Additions ==
=== Command format ===
'''[[Item stack component]]s'''
* Added new item stack components.
* Added <code>food</code> item stack component.
** When present, this item behaves as if a food (can be eaten)
** Format: object with fields:
*** <code>nutrition</code>: non-negative integer, number of food points to restore when eaten.
*** <code>saturation_modifier</code>: float, amount of saturation to restore when eaten.
*** <code>can_always_eat</code>: boolean (default: <code>false</code>)
**** If <code>true</code>, this food can be eaten even if not hungry.
*** <code>eat_seconds</code>: float (default: <code>1.6</code>)
**** The number of seconds that it takes to eat this food item.
*** <code>effects</code>: list of effects to apply when eaten (default: <code>[]</code>)
**** <code>effect</code>: effect instance (same format as <code>custom_effects</code> in <code>minecraft:potion_contents</code> component)
**** <code>probability</code>: float between 0 and 1, chance for the effect to be applied (default: <code>1</code>)
*** Example: <code>food={nutrition:4,saturation_modifier:0.1}</code>
** On food items, has an implicit default value for that food type.
* Added <code>max_stack_size</code>.
** Controls the maximum stacking size of this item.
** Format: integer between 1 and 99.
*** Example: <code>max_stack_size=4</code>
** Has an implicit default value according to the item type (usually <code>64</code> but can also be <code>16</code> and <code>1</code>)
* Added <code>max_damage</code>.
** Controls the maximum amount of damage than an item can take.
** If not present, the item cannot be damaged.
** Format: positive integer.
*** Example: <code>max_damage=123</code>
** Has an implicit default value for damageable items.
* Added <code>fire_resistant</code>.
** If present, this item doesn't burn in fire.
** Format: empty object.
*** Example: <code>fire_resistant={}</code>
** Has an implicit default value for fire-resistant items, such as netherite tools.
* Added <code>rarity</code>.
** Controls the color of the item name.
** Format: enumerated value, one of:
*** <code>common</code> (default): white name, or aqua when enchanted.
*** <code>uncommon</code>: yellow name, or aqua when enchanted.
*** <code>rare</code>: aqua name, or light purple when enchanted.
*** <code>epic</code>: light purple name.
*** Example: <code>rarity=rare</code>.
** Special items such as [[golden apple]]s have an implicit default value.
* Added <code>tool</code>.
** Controls the behavior of the item as a tool.
** Format: object with fields.
*** <code>rules</code>: list of rule entries.
**** <code>blocks</code>: single block, list of blocks, or #-prefixed block tag to match.
**** <code>speed</code> (optional): float, overrides the mining speed if present and matched.
**** <code>correct_for_drops</code> (optional): boolean, overrides whether this tool is considered 'correct' if present and matched.
***** <code>true</code> causes the block to mine at its most efficient speed, and drop items if the targeted block requires that.
*** <code>default_mining_speed</code>: float, mining speed to use if no rules match and override mining speed (default: 1.0).
*** <code>damage_per_block</code>: non-negative int, amount of durability to remove each time a block is mined with this tool.
*** Example: <code>tool={rules:[{blocks:"#mineable/pickaxe",speed:4.0,correct_for_drops:true}]}</code>
** Vanilla tool items have an implicit default value based on their tier and tool type.
* Added <code>hide_tooltip</code>.
** If present, it completely hides whole item tooltip (that includes item name).
** Tooltip is still visible and searchable in Creative mode.
** Format: empty object.
*** Example: <code>hide_tooltip={}</code>

'''[[Loot functions]]'''
* Added <code>toggle_tooltips</code> loot function.
** This function can be used to modify item component tooltip visiblity.
** It works by setting fields like <code>show_in_tooltip</code> without changing other values.
** Format: <code>toggles</code> - a map of supported item component type to boolean value.
** Supported components: <code>trim</code>, <code>dyed_color</code>, <code>enchantments</code>, <code>stored_enchantments</code>, <code>unbreakable</code>, <code>can_break</code>, <code>can_place_on</code>, <code>attribute_modifiers</code>.
** Example: <code>{function:"toggle_tooltips","toggles":{"enchantments":false}}</code> hides enchantments tooltip.

'''[[Loot table]]s'''
* Added <code>storage</code> loot number provider to access values from command storage.
** This number provider is able to access numeric values from command storage directly.
** If selected storage does not exist or tag selected by path is not numeric or does not exist, provider returns 0.
** Fields:
*** <code>storage</code>: namespaced id of command storage.
*** <code>path</code>: NBT path to field.

=== Gameplay ===
'''[[Advancement]]s'''
* Added a <code>crafter_recipe_crafted</code> trigger which is triggered when a [[crafter]] ejects a successfully crafted item into the world.
** <code><player></code> an entity predicate matching the player who is nearby.
** <code><recipe_id></code> is the ID of the recipe being crafted.
** <code><ingredients></code> is a list of item predicates matching the ingredients that form the recipe being crafted.
* Added a <code>fall_after_explosion</code> trigger which is triggered when a player begins falling after being knocked upwards by an explosion or wind burst.
** <code><player></code> an entity predicate matching the player who is falling.
** <code><start_position></code> a location predicate matching the position the player was at when they were hit by the explosion or burst.
** <code><distance></code> a distance predicate matching how far the player must be from <code>start_position</code> to cause the trigger to activate.
** <code><cause></code> an entity predicate matching the entity which caused the explosion or burst to happen.

=== General ===
'''[[Tag]]s'''
* Added <code>incorrect_for_wooden_tool</code>, <code>incorrect_for_gold_tool</code>, <code>incorrect_for_stone_tool</code>, <code>incorrect_for_iron_tool</code>, <code>incorrect_for_diamond_tool</code>, <code>incorrect_for_netherite_tool</code> block tags.
** These tags combine the existing <code>needs_diamond_tool</code>, <code>needs_iron_tool</code>, and <code>needs_stone_tool</code> tags for each specific tool tier.
* Added <code>meat</code> collection item tag.
** Contains {{cd|d=and|beef|chicken|cooked_beef|cooked_chicken|cooked_mutton|cooked_porkchop|cooked_rabbit|mutton|porkchop|rabbit|rotten_flesh}} 
** This is not used by the game directly, but may be included by other tags.
* Added {{cd|d=and|#armadillo_food|#bee_food|#camel_food|#cat_food|#chicken_food|#cow_food|#frog_food|#goat_food|#hoglin_food|#horse_food|#horse_tempt_items|#llama_food|#llama_tempt_items|#ocelot_food|#panda_food|#parrot_food|#parrot_poisonous_food|#pig_food|#rabbit_food|#sheep_food|#strider_food|#strider_tempt_items|#turtle_food|#wolf_food}} item tags to control which items can be fed to or tempt the corresponding mobs.
* Added <code>sensitive_to_smite</code> entity type tag.
** For entity types that take extra damage from the [[Smite]] enchantment.

== Changes ==
=== Command format ===
'''General'''
* Command arguments that previously accepted namespaced ids of loot tables, modifiers and predicates can now also accept inline definitions:
** <code>loot</code>
** <code>item</code>
** <code>execute if predicate</code>
** Values have same structure as matching JSON files, though they are encoded as SNBT. Example: <code>execute if predicate {condition:weather_check, raining:true}</code>

'''[[Entity sub-predicates]]'''
* <code>wolf</code>
** New <code>wolf</code> sub-predicate has been added to match wolf variantsFields: <code>variant</code> - wolf variant to match (single entry, list of entries or tag)
* <code>cat</code>, <code>frog</code>, <code>painting</code>
** Field <code>variant</code> now accepts single entries, list of entries or tags.
* <code>wolf</code>, <code>cat</code>, <code>frog</code> and <code>painting</code> entity sub-predicates now accept tags and plain lists instead of just single elements.

'''[[Loot functions]]'''
*<code>set_lore</code> function:
** The <code>replace</code> field has been removed.
** Now has <code>mode</code> like <code>set_fireworks</code> and <code>set_written_book_pages</code>.
* <code>set_written_book_pages</code> function:
** <code>pages</code> is now a JSON object rather than a string containing JSON.
* Nested lists are no longer supported in function lists.

'''[[Item predicate argument]]'''
* The item predicate syntax (used in <code>execute if|unless items</code> and <code>clear</code> commands) has been significantly expanded.
* The general syntax is: <code><type> [comma-separated list of <test>]</code>
* <code><type></code> can be one of:
** item id
** item tag id prefixed with <code>#</code>
** <code>*</code> to match any item.
* <code><test></code> can have one of 3 forms:
** <code><component_id>=<value></code> - match exact value of component (same as in previous format)
*** <code><value></code> is a representation of component value in SNBT format (same as in <code>item give</code> argument)
** <code><component_id></code> - check if component exists.
** <code><predicate_id>~<value></code> - check item sub-predicate.
*** <code><value></code> is a representation of item sub-predicate in SNBT format (but otherwise same as one used for advancement and loot table JSON files)
*** Example: <code>*[damage~{durability:{min:3}}]</code> matches any stack with at least 3 uses left.
* The special name <code>minecraft:count</code> can be used for matching the stack size.
** <code>count=<positive int></code> passes only when the stack size equals the given value.
** <code>count~<int range></code> passes when the stack size is in the specified range.
*** Example: <code>*[count~{max:2}]</code> matches any stack with count <= 2.
** <code>count</code> always passes.
* Any <code><test></code> entry can be negated by prefixing with <code>!</code>
** Example: <code>*[!count=1]</code> matches any stack that has count other than 1.
* <code><test></code> elements can be also joined with | to check multiple alternatives.
** Example: <code>*[!damage|damage=0]</code> looks for items without damage component or with 0 damage.
* Removed redundant custom data section (<code>{...}</code>) from item arguments (it's fully replaced by <code>[custom_data={...}]</code>)
** To make this transition easier, <code>custom_data</code> item sub-predicate has been changed to allow unquoted SNBT.
* The syntax for custom data partial matching (<code>{}</code>) has been removed in favor of using <code>custom_data</code> predicates.
** So <code>stick{a:2}</code> becomes <code>stick[custom_data~{a:2}]</code>

'''[[Item sub-predicates]]'''
* Predicate <code>minecraft:custom_data</code> now accepts both SNBT data written as a string (existing format) and unflattened tags.
** That means that <code>*[custom_data~{a:1}]</code> and <code>*[custom_data~"{a:1}"]</code> are equivalent.
** Flattened string format has been kept since NBT type information can't be expressed in JSON.

=== General ===
'''[[Data pack]]s'''
* The data pack version is now <code>36</code>.

'''[[Resource pack]]s'''
* The resource pack version is now <code>30</code>.
* Changed texture asset paths in <code>wolf_variant</code> to better match other formats.
** Field <code>texture</code> has been renamed to <code>wild_texture</code>
** <code>wild_texture</code>, <code>tame_texture</code> and <code>angry_texture</code> no longer require values to be prefixed with <code>textures/</code> and suffixed with <code>.png</code>.
* Particle <code>entity_effect</code> takes color argument when spawned from command <code>/particle entity_effect {{cd|r}} {{cd|g}} {{cd|b}} {{cd|a}}</code>.
** 4 float values ranging from 0.0 to 1.0 representing RGBA.
* Removed <code>map_icons.png</code>{{more info}}
** Map decoration icons have been split from the former <code>map_icons.png</code> to use an atlas loaded from the <code>textures/map/decorations/</code> directory.
** The atlas is now generated upon loading resources: [[map_decorations.png-atlas]]
* The process of upgrading a pack can be assisted by using an automated Slicer tool.<ref>https://github.com/Mojang/slicer/releases/tag/v1.1.4</ref>
* Added <code>trial_chambers</code> map decoration icon.

'''[[Tag]]s'''
* <code>axolotl_tempt_items</code> has been renamed to <code>axolotl_food</code>.

== Experimental ==
=== Additions ===
==== Items ====
'''[[File:Trial Chambers Map JE1.png|32px]] [[Trial chambers map]]'''
* Can be traded from journeyman cartographers.
* Point to a nearby [[trial chamber]].

==== Gameplay ====
'''[[Advancement]]s'''
* Added seven new advancements:
** Minecraft: Trial(s) Edition 
*** Step foot in a Trial Chamber
** Under Lock & Key 
*** Unlock a Vault using a Trial Key
** Blowback
*** Kill a Breeze with a deflected Wind Charge
** Who Needs Rockets?
*** Use a Wind Charge to launch yourself upward at least 8 blocks
** Crafters Crafting Crafters
*** Be near a Crafter when it crafts a Crafter
** Lighten Up
*** Scrape a Copper Bulb with an Axe to make it brighter
** Over-Overkill
*** Deal 50 hearts of damage in a single hit using the Mace

==== General ====
'''[[Tag]]s'''
* Added the <code>#on_trial_chambers_maps</code> structure tag.
** Contains <code>trial_chambers</code>.

=== Changes ===
==== Blocks ====
'''[[Heavy core]]'''
* Can now be waterlogged.
* Can now survive lava flowing into them.
* Adjusted destroy time and explosion resistance.
** It now takes 15 seconds to mine (down from 45).
** Blast resistance now matches the one from [[obsidian]].
* Pushing a heavy core with a [[piston]] now moves the block, instead of popping it off.
* [[Map]] color is now silver.
* Removed the unused <code>orientation</code> block state.

==== Items ====
'''[[Mace]]'''
* No longer counts as an efficient tool for breaking [[cobweb]]s.
* Maces now have a unique sound when hitting an entity from a fall of more than five blocks.

==== World generation ====
'''[[Trial chambers]]'''
* Now generate slightly more rarely and a bit more spaced out from each other.
